page.content:
Research shows that teachers need to increase the amount of student writing practice. Find out why, and learn about about Quick Writes, a writing activity that can add to our instruction to help students get more writing practice and increase their confidence as writers.

Research shows that teachers need to increase the amount of student writing practice. Why?

Writing practice

  • Improves writing;
  • Improves reading;
  • Can deepen thinking about content;
  • Can increase writing fluency;
  • Can makes students more comfortable and confident about writing;
  • Can promote transfer between contexts.

Quick Writes are a good way to increase student writing. Incorporate Quick Writes into your teaching practice.

Quick Writes are...

  • A strategy for develping writing fluency.
  • Non-threatening, non-graded.
  • Informal and quick.
  • Motivational.
  • Opportunities for reflection and elaboration.

Quick Writes

  • Provide opportunities for readers to strengthen their comprehension through writing.
  • Deepen writers' thinking about a topic as a writing-to-learn activity.
  • Support progress toward one or more specific writing goals (i.e., longer compositions, more details, or more complex sentences).
  • Desensitize students to the fear of a blank page.

How Do Quick Writes Work?

  • Ask learners to take 5 minutes to respond to a question or prompt that you pose. The prompt can relate to a reading that students have just done (or are about to do), or it can ask them to name a favorite movie and discuss why they like it. As a formative assessment tool, the quick write topic can ask students to tell what they learned in class today/tonight and to list questions they still have about the topic.
  • Explain to students that they should write whatever comes to their minds about the prompt, and that they need not be concerned with spelling, punctuation, grammar, etc.
  • During the quick write, the teacher always writes, too!

Use Quick Writes as a

  • Warm up activities to start class;
  • Reinforcement to comprehension;
  • Pre-discussion focusing activity;
  • Pre-writing brainstorm activity to elicit ideas, prior knowledge, and vocabulary;
  • Formative assessment tool.

Benefits of Quick Writes

  • They bring out the writer in students.
  • They build students' confidence.
  • They develop writing fluency, especially if used frequently.
  • They bring out the reader in students.
  • They also help teachers grow as writers!

When using Quick Writes, keep these key components in mind:

  • Enforce the rules: No talking and EVERYONE writes – including the instructor!
  • Five minutes or less.
  • Try to stay on topic, but it's more important to keep writing.
  • Debrief to ask for ideas or words that were generated.
